{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox convention | name = PAX | image = PAX new logo, blue.svg | caption = | status = Active | genre = Gaming (video game, tabletop, CCG, role-playing) | venue = [[Washington State Convention Center]] (PAX West, PAX Dev)
[[Boston Convention and Exhibition Center]] (PAX East)
[[Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre]] (PAX Australia)
[[Henry B. Gonzalez Convention Center]] (PAX South)
[[Pennsylvania Convention Center]] (PAX Unplugged) | location = [[Seattle, Washington]] (PAX West, PAX Dev)
[[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]] (PAX East)
[[Melbourne]], [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]] (PAX Australia)
[[San Antonio]], [[Texas]] (PAX South)
[[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] (PAX Unplugged) | country = [[United States]] (PAX West, PAX Dev, PAX East, PAX South, PAX Unplugged)
[[Australia]] (PAX Australia) | first = {{start date and age|2004|8|28}} (as Penny Arcade Expo) (PAX West)
{{start date|2010|3|26}} (PAX East)
{{start date|2011|8|26}} (PAX Dev)
{{start date|2013|7|19}} (PAX Australia)
{{start date|2015|1|23}} (PAX South)
{{start date|2017|11|17}} (PAX Unplugged) | last = PAX West 2018, [[Seattle, Washington]] | organizer = ''[[Penny Arcade (webcomic)|Penny Arcade]]'', [[Reed Exhibitions]] | filing = | attendance = 70,000+ (2011, PAX Prime) 80,000+ (2017, PAX East) | website = [http://www.paxsite.com www.paxsite.com] }} '''PAX''' (originally known as '''Penny Arcade Expo''') is an overall term used to refer to a series of gaming culture festivals that involve; [[Tabletop game|tabletop gaming]], [[Arcade game|arcade gaming]], and [[video game|video gaming]]. PAX festival events are held annually in [[Seattle|Seattle, Washington]]; [[Boston|Boston, Massachusetts]]; [[Philadelphia|Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]; [[San Antonio|San Antonio, Texas]]; and [[Melbourne|Melbourne, Australia]]. PAX was originally created by [[Jerry Holkins]] and [[Mike Krahulik]], the authors of the ''[[Penny Arcade (webcomic)|Penny Arcade]]'' [[webcomic]], because they wanted to attend a show exclusively for gaming.{{cite web|title=PAX East History|url=http://east.paxsite.com/what-is-pax|website=PAX East|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160301014352/http://east.paxsite.com/what-is-pax|archivedate=March 1, 2016}} PAX was first held in 2004. Defining characteristics of the festivals include an opening keynote speech from an industry insider, game-culture inspired concerts, panels on game topics, exhibitor booths from both independent and major game developers and publishers, a [[LAN party]] [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]], tabletop gaming tournaments, and video game freeplay areas. Every PAX also features the Omegathon, a festival-long tournament consisting of a group of randomly selected attendees competing for a grand prize. The final round of the Omegathon makes up part of the closing ceremonies of PAX. Past games for the final round of the Omegathon have included ''[[Tetris]]'', ''[[Pong]]'', ''[[Halo 3]]'', and [[skee-ball]]. == History == {{Main article|History of PAX}} [[File:Pennyarcadeexpocrowd.jpg|thumb|left|Crowds filling the Meydenbauer Center at PAX 2006]] The first PAX, known at the time as the ''Penny Arcade'' Expo, was held on August 28–29, 2004, in [[Bellevue, Washington]], at the [[Meydenbauer Center]], and was attended by approximately 3,300 people. The event was then held annually in August, at the same venue, for the next two years. Attendance grew rapidly, with over 9,000 attendees in 2005, and over 19,000 in 2006. [[File:PAX 2009 - Wil Wheaton (3888471061).jpg|thumb|left|Actor [[Wil Wheaton]] signs autographs at PAX 2009]] By 2007, the event had outgrown its previous venue, and moved to the [[Washington State Convention and Trade Center]], which was twice the size. Attendance in 2007 was counted at 39,000.{{cite web|last= Magrino |first= Tom |title= PAX 2010 descends on Boston |url= http://www.gamespot.com/news/6197016.html |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gamespot.com%2Fnews%2F6197016.html&date=2009-09-07 |work= Gamespot |publisher= [[CBS Interactive]] |date= August 29, 2009 |archivedate= September 7, 2009 |accessdate= September 7, 2009 |deadurl=no}} In 2008, attendance grew to 58,500, and in 2009, it grew to 60,750. In 2010, PAX held its first event on the East Coast. PAX East 2010 was held in Boston, from March 26–28, at the [[Hynes Convention Center]]. Attendance levels rivaled those of PAX 2009; PAX East 2010 was attended by 52,290. From then on, the original Washington festival was referred to as PAX Prime in order to avoid confusion between the two. PAX Prime 2010 was attended by 67,600 people, and involved off-site events for the first time. PAX Prime 2011 was attended by over 70,000 people. For the two days prior to PAX Prime, an event called PAX Dev was held; it was exclusive to the game developer community, no press were permitted, and it was attended by 750 people. This supplemental event was created as a forum where "developers [could] speak freely and focus entirely on their trade".{{cite web |url=http://dev.paxsite.com/faqs.php |title=PAX Dev FAQs |publisher=dev.paxsite.com |date= |accessdate=April 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331161611/http://dev.paxsite.com/faqs.php |archivedate=March 31, 2012 }} The same year, the second annual PAX East was held in March 2011, at a new venue, the [[Boston Convention and Exhibition Center]]. [[File:PAX East 2012 Expo Hall.jpg|thumb|left|The expo hall at PAX East 2012]] PAX East 2012 was held April 6–8, and PAX Prime 2012 was held from August 31 to September 2, on Labor Day weekend. [[File:Rooster Teeth panel at PAX Prime 2013 (9669012406).jpg|thumb|right|Members of [[Rooster Teeth]] host a panel at PAX Prime 2013]] PAX East 2013 took place March 22–24. 2013 also marked the first year that a PAX event was held outside of the United States; PAX Australia 2013 was held July 19–21, 2013 at the [[Melbourne Showgrounds]]. PAX Prime 2013 was the first four-day PAX and took place from August 30 to September 2, 2013. Passes for PAX Prime 2013 sold out within six hours. An agreement reached in early 2012 has extended Boston as the home of PAX East until 2023.{{cite news |author=Herald Staff |url=http://news.bostonherald.com/business/general/view/20220215pax_east_commits_to_boston_for_10_more_years/ |title=PAX East commits to Boston for 10 more years |work=[[Boston Herald]] |date=February 15, 2012 |accessdate=April 7, 2012}} [[File:Darksiders cosplayers (30547697728).jpg|thumb|right|[[Cosplay]]ers pose for a photo at PAX West 2018.]] PAX Australia 2014 was held at the [[Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre]] on October 31 to November 2, 2014, where it was confirmed that the exhibition will remain in Melbourne until 2019.{{cite web |title=PAX Australia on Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/PAXAus/status/526865401666228224 |publisher=[[Twitter]] |accessdate=December 31, 2014 |date=October 27, 2014}} The first PAX South was held in [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]] at the [[Henry B. Gonzalez Convention Center]] on January 23–25, 2015. It set a PAX record for highest attendance for an inaugural year.[http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/01/26/pax-south-attendance-breaks-records PAX South Attendance Breaks Records]. [[IGN]]. January 25, 2015. PAX East 2015 was held on March 6–8 at the [[Boston Convention and Exhibition Center]]. PAX Prime 2015 was held at the [[Washington State Convention Center]] on August 28–31. PAX Australia 2015 was held on [[Melbourne Cup]] weekend, on October 30 to November 1 at the [[Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre]]. On November 18, 2015, it was silently confirmed that PAX Prime was being renamed to ''PAX West''.{{cite web|last1=Khoo|first1=Robert|title=Robert Khoo on Twitter: "@skelevader b/c if i make an announcement people will read too much into it. Besides, press releases are lame. PAX WEST FOR LIFE."|url=https://twitter.com/rkhoo/status/667122653820542976|website=Twitter|accessdate=February 26, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160226054359/https://twitter.com/rkhoo/status/667122653820542976|archivedate=February 26, 2016|deadurl=no|date=November 18, 2015}} PAX South 2016 was held on January 29–31 at the [[Henry B. Gonzalez Convention Center]] in San Antonio, Texas. PAX East 2016 was held on April 22–24 at the [[Boston Convention and Exhibition Center]]. PAX West 2016 (formerly PAX Prime) was held on September 2–5 at the [[Washington State Convention Center]]. PAX Australia 2016 was held on November 4–6 at the [[Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre]]. PAX South 2017 was held on January 27–29 at the [[Henry B. Gonzalez Convention Center]] in San Antonio, Texas. During this time, it was announced that Penny Arcade would be hosting another event known as PAXUnplugged. Designed as a tabletop-exclusive convention, it took place November 17–19, 2017 at the [[Pennsylvania Convention Center]], in [[Philadelphia]].{{Cite web|url=http://unplugged.paxsite.com/|title=PAX Unplugged - Philadelphia, PA Nov. 17 - 19, 2017|website=unplugged.paxsite.com|access-date=March 14, 2017}} PAX East was held on March 10–12 at the [[Boston Convention and Exhibition Center]]. PAX West 2017 was held on September 1–4, 2017 at the [[Washington State Convention Center]]. PAX Dev 2017 was held on August 29–30, 2017. PAX Aus 2017 was held on October 27-29, 2017 at the [[Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre]]. PAX South 2018 was held on January 12-14, 2018. PAX East 2018 was held on April 5-8, 2018. 2018 was the first year PAX East spanned 4 days, similar to PAX West. Unlike West, it ran from a Thursday to a Sunday, as opposed to a Friday to a Monday. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * {{Official website|http://www.paxsite.com}} {{Penny Arcade}} {{Reed Elsevier}} {{Video Game Trade Shows}} {{Washington State Fandom Conventions}} [[Category:Annual events in Boston]] [[Category:Culture of Seattle]] [[Category:ESports competitions]] [[Category:Festivals in Seattle]] [[Category:Gaming conventions]] [[Category:LAN parties]] [[Category:Multigenre conventions]] [[Category:Penny Arcade (webcomic)|Expo]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2004]] [[Category:Seattle Area conventions]]

[[image:Suvée Festa di Pales.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|''Festa di Pales, o L'estate'' (1783), a reimagining of the Festival of Pales by [[Joseph-Benoît Suvée]]]] In [[Religion in ancient Rome|ancient Roman religion]], the '''Parilia''' is a [[Roman festival|festival]] of rural character performed annually on 21 April, aimed at cleansing both sheep and shepherd. It is carried out in acknowledgment to the Roman deity [[Pales]], a deity of uncertain gender who was a patron of shepherds and sheep.<ref name="one">''The Cambridge Ancient History 2nd Ed. Vol. X: The Augustan Empire 43 BC – AD 69''. Cambridge University Press. Great Britain: 1996. pp. 816-817</ref>
[[Ovid]] describes the Parilia at length in the ''[[Fasti (Ovid)|Fasti]]'', an [[elegiac couplets|elegiac]] poem on the [[Roman calendar|Roman religious calendar]], and implies that it predates the [[founding of Rome]], traditionally 753 BC, as indicated by its [[pastoral]], pre-agricultural concerns. During the [[Roman Republic|Republic]], [[Roman agriculture|farming]] was idealized and central to Roman identity, so the festival took on a more generally rural character. Increasing urbanization caused the rustic Parilia to be reinterpreted rather than abandoned, as Rome was an [[mos maiorum|intensely traditional society]]. During the [[Roman Empire|Imperial period]], the date was celebrated as the "birthday" of Rome ''([[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#dies natalis|dies natalis]] Romae)''.
==Ceremony==
The pastoral structure of the festival is carried out by the shepherd himself. After the sheep pen had been decorated with green branches and a wreath draped on the gate, the remainder of the ceremony took place in sequence. At the first sign of daylight, the shepherd would purify the sheep: by sweeping the pen and then constructing a bonfire of straw, olive branches, [[Bay Laurel|laurel]], and sulfur. The noises produced by this burning combination were interpreted as a beneficial omen. The shepherd would jump through this flame, dragging his sheep along with him. Offerings of [[millet]], cakes, and milk were then presented before [[Pales]], marking the second segment of the ceremony. After these offerings, the shepherd would wet his hands with dew, face the east, and repeat a prayer four times. Such prayers requested Pales’s assistance in freeing the shepherd and the flock from evils brought about by accidental wrongdoings (e.g. trespassing on sacred grounds and removing water from a sacred water source).<ref name="two">Fowler, Warde W. ''The Roman Festivals of the Period of the Republic''. MacMillan and CO, Limited. London: 1899. pp. 79-85.</ref> The final portion of the rural festival made use of the beverage burranica, a combination of milk and ''[[Defrutum|sapa]]'' (boiled wine). After consumption of this beverage, the shepherd would leap through the fire three times, bringing an end to the ceremony.<ref name="three">Butrica, James L. ''Propertius on the Parilia'' (4.4.73-8). Classical Quarterly 50.2. Memorial University of Newfoundland. Great Britain: 2000. pp. 472-478.</ref>
The urban form of the Parilia, on the other hand, is blended with other Roman religious practices and carried out by a priest. Ovid personally participated in this form and describes his experiences in the ''Fasti''.<ref name="four">Ovid. ''Fasti''; Gower, John. ''Ovids Festivalls, or Romane calendar, translated into English verse equinumerally''. London: 1640. pp. 93-97.</ref> While the central actions of the rural ceremony carry over, the urban form adds two ingredients from other religious festivals: the Fordicidia and the [[October Horse]]. The [[Fordicidia]] sacrifices a pregnant cow to the deity [[Terra (mythology)|Tellus]] to promote cattle and field fertility. The unborn calf is then removed from the womb and burnt. The [[October Horse]] is the right hand horse of the team that won a particular chariot race on October 15 of the previous year.<ref name="five">Adkins, Lesley & Roy A. ''Dictionary of Roman Religion''. Facts on File Inc. New York: 1996. pp. 82, 168.</ref> Together, the ashes of the unborn calf and the blood from the head of the October Horse are mixed by the [[Vestals]] and are added to the burning bean straw of the bonfire.<ref name="two"/> [[Dumézil]] questioned whether the ''Equus October'' provided the horse blood,<ref>G. Dumezil ''La religion romaine archaique'' Paris, 1974, part 1, chap. 4 "Mars".</ref> since the two ancient sources that mention the ingredient omit identifying the victim.<ref>Propertius ''Elegiae Romanae'' 4, 1, 19-20 (where the horse is described as ''curtus'', "dismembered"); Ovid ''Fasti'' IV, 721 sqq. The October Horse, however, is the only horse sacrifice known to have been practiced regularly by the Romans.</ref>
==History==
By the end of the late Republic, the Parilia became associated with the birthday of Rome.<ref name="six">Kearns, Emily. ''The Oxford Dictionary of Classical Myth and Religion''. Oxford University Press. Oxford: 2003. pp. 406.</ref> Numerous accounts of the founding of Rome exist, but the particular one related to the Parilia is described by Ovid in his ''[[Fasti (poem)|Fasti]]''. According to this myth, [[Romulus]], upon reaching Rome on the day of the Parilia, took a stick and engraved a line in the ground that defined the boundaries of the new city ''([[pomerium]])''. He then prayed to the gods [[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]], [[Mars (mythology)|Mars]], and [[Vesta (mythology)|Vesta]] asking for protection of this area. However, his brother [[Remus]], unaware of the boundaries, crossed the line and was struck down by Romulus's henchman [[Celer (builder)|Celer]].<ref name="four"/>
Over time, and under the influence of several Roman rulers, the structure of the Parilia changed. First, after [[Julius Caesar]] heard the news of Roman Victory at [[Battle of Munda|Munda]] in 45 BC (around the date of the Parilia), he added games to the ceremony. At these games, the citizens would wear crowns in Caesar’s honor. Caligula instituted into the celebration a procession of priests, noblemen, boys and girls of noble birth singing of his virtues while escorting the Golden Shield, previously bestowed upon him by the citizens of Rome, to the Capitol.{{cn|date=June 2013}} At this time the Parilia became Rome's birthday celebration rather than the rural festival it had once been.{{cn|date=June 2013}} In 121 AD [[Hadrian]] founded a new temple of Venus and Roma and changed the festival’s name to Romaea. The temple was ruined.{{clarify|date=October 2016 |reason=which temple ruined by whom and when?}}<ref name="one"/> <ref>Charles River Editors (2013-02-14). Caligula & Nero: Rome’s Worst Emperors (Kindle Locations 715-716). Charles River Editors. Kindle Edition. </ref>

{{multiple image |total_width=355 |image1=Mitt Romney by Gage Skidmore 8.jpg|width1=2234|height1=2904 |caption1=Mitt Romney |image2=Mike Leavitt.jpg|width2=2400|height2=3000 |caption2=[[Mike Leavitt]] (2005) |footer=Former [[HHS Secretary]] Leavitt chaired the team that would have coordinated the presidential transition for Romney. }} The '''planned presidential transition of Mitt Romney''', better known as the '''Romney Readiness Project''', refers to the [[United States presidential transition|planned transfer of power]] from [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] to [[Mitt Romney]], the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]'s candidate for president in the [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential election]]. Because Barack Obama was reelected as President, the transition did not take place.
The transition plan was the first to occur under the terms of the 2010 Pre-election Presidential Transition Act.<ref name="ClarkReadiness"/>
The Edward "Ted" Kaufman and Michael Leavitt Presidential Transitions Improvements Act of 2015 was named in Leavitt's honor and also in honor of the head of the [[Obama transition team]].
==Planning the transition== {{Further information|Mitt Romney presidential campaign, 2012#"Readiness Project"}} Known internally as "The Readiness Project", transition planning began in April 2012, several months before the [[2012 Republican National Convention]].<ref name="KeaneTransition">{{cite news|last1=Keane|first1=Angela|title=Trump Campaign Upends the Science of Presidential Transition|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-05-06/trump-s-campaign-upends-the-science-of-presidential-transition|accessdate=May 13, 2016|publisher=[[Bloomberg Politics]]|date=May 6, 2016}}</ref> Led by [[Mike Leavitt]], it consisted of a skeleton staff of four until August, when additional employees were retained. The staff eventually grew to almost 300 people.<ref name="SteinmetzTeam">{{cite news|last1=Steinmetz|first1=Katy|title=Planning a Presidency That Never Was: Inside the Romney Transition Team|url=http://swampland.time.com/2012/11/15/planning-a-presidency-that-never-was-inside-the-romney-transition-team/|accessdate=May 13, 2016|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=November 15, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Hayden|first1=Eric|title=Mitt Romney's Transition Website: Where 'President-Elect' Romney Lives On|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2012/11/08/mitt-romneys-transition-website-where-president-elect-romney/|accessdate=January 22, 2016|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=November 8, 2012}}</ref><ref name="parker"/> Other senior executives within the project included [[Robert Zoellick]] and [[Allan B. Hubbard|Al Hubbard]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Palmer|first1=Anna|title=Mitt transition efforts intensifying|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2012/09/mitt-transition-efforts-intensifying-081600?o=1|accessdate=January 22, 2016|work=[[Politico]]|date=September 24, 2012}}</ref>
Activities undertaken by the Readiness Project included preparing policy briefings for [[United States federal civil service|civil servant]]s at federal agencies, which would be delivered by "parachute teams" following the election; creating a list of candidates to fill the several hundred [[List of positions filled by presidential appointment with Senate confirmation|political appointments made by the President]]; coordinating with the [[Obama administration]] for the transfer of occupancy of presidential residences, including the [[White House]] and the [[Number One Observatory Circle]]; liaising with the [[United States Armed Forces]] for the assumption of [[National Command Authority]] and launch control of [[nuclear weapon]]s; and developing a post-election communications plan, which reportedly included a 1,000-word victory speech Romney would deliver.<ref name="parker">{{cite news|last1=Parker|first1=Ashley|author-link=Ashley Parker (journalist)|title=Campaigning Aside, Team Plans a Romney Presidency|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/17/us/politics/mitt-romneys-transition-team-is-hard-at-work.html|accessdate=January 22, 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=August 16, 2012}}</ref><ref name="nr"/> On the evening of the election, the Readiness Project's transition website, declaring Romney's victory, was accidentally pushed live, but was quickly taken down again. The site was built by a Utah-based web development company, SolutionStream.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Eaton|first1=Kit|title=If Mitt Romney Had Won, Is This What His Website Would've Looked Like?|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3002828/if-mitt-romney-had-won-what-his-website-wouldve-looked|accessdate=January 22, 2016|work=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]|date=November 8, 2012}}</ref>
In accordance with the Pre-Election Presidential Transition Act of 2010, the project was provided with office space by the [[General Services Administration]] (GSA) beginning in September 2012, two months prior to the election.<ref name="parker"/><ref name="nr" /> The offices of the Readiness Project were shuttered and completely cleared within three days following Romney's defeat. Total spending by the Readiness Project between its inception and dissolution was $8.9 million, with those costs paid by the U.S. government.<ref name="nr">{{cite news|last1=Fund|first1=John|author-link=John Fund|title=What was Romney Planning?|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/338182/what-was-romney-planning-john-fund|accessdate=January 22, 2016|work=[[National Review]]|date=January 13, 2013}}</ref>
===Contingency=== The Romney team was reported as having shaken off the fear of appearing presumptuous, a fear that hampered the Obama team and hindered them from making adequate transition preparations.<ref name="BermanTakeover">{{cite news|last1=Berman|first1=Russell|title=The Most Important Takeover of Any Organization in History|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/04/improving-the-presidential-transition-2016/477528/|accessdate=May 29, 2016|work=[[The Atlantic]]|date=April 22, 2016}}</ref>
In contrast with the Obama presidential transition, Leavitt communicated directly with [[White House Chief of Staff]] [[Jack Lew]], and the two coordinated a plan, putting members of the transition team in charge of various government departments in direct communication with members of the Obama administration. Leavitt described his new style of transition team as "essentially a federal government in miniature."<ref name="BermanTakeover"/>
==Impact== The [[Ted Kaufman|Edward "Ted" Kaufman]] and Michael Leavitt Presidential Transitions Improvements Act of 2015 was named in Leavitt's honor and also in honor of the head of the Obama transition team. The organization said, "The new law creates a federal overseer for the presidential transition and requires each agency to name a person to manage the process."<ref name="KeaneTransition"/>
Leavitt agreed to work on the [[Planned presidential transition of Donald Trump|planning for Donald Trump's presidential transition]], even though he had not endorsed Trump.<ref name="CanhamLeavitt">{{cite news|last1=Canham|first1=Mike|title=Former Gov. Mike Leavitt advising Donald Trump's transition team|url=http://www.sltrib.com/news/3914426-155/former-gov-mike-leavitt-advising-donald|accessdate=May 22, 2016|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|date=May 20, 2014}}</ref> According to ''[[The Washington Post]]'', Leavitt is regarded as an "evangelist for how to run an effective presidential transition."<ref name="ReinUnlikely">{{cite news|last1=Rein|first1=Lisa|title=As he begins transition planning, Trump turns to unlikely source: Romney-world|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2016/05/20/as-he-begins-transition-planning-trump-turns-to-unlikely-source-romney-world/|accessdate=May 22, 2016|work=The Washington Post|date=May 20, 2016}}</ref> Leavitt stated that he was lending the Trump team his "unique experience" because "[c]ountries are vulnerable during transitions and I see this as a very—almost obligation—to contribute to the country. This is a very serious thing."<ref name="FauldersTransition">{{cite news|last1=Faulders|first1=Katherine|title=Donald Trump Camp Enlists Former Romney Aide Mike Leavitt in Transition Talks|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trump-camp-enlists-romney-aide-mike-leavitt/story?id=39257726|accessdate=May 26, 2016|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=May 20, 2016}}</ref>
===Report by Leavitt=== In 2013, Leavitt published a 138-page case study of the Readiness Project entitled ''Romney Readiness Project 2012: Retrospectives and Lessons Learned''.<ref name="KeaneTransition"/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Hicken|first1=Jackie|title=Blueprint outlines work former Utah Gov. Mike Leavitt, others did to prepare for President Romney|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/765630884/Blueprint-outlines-work-former-Utah-Gov-Mike-Leavitt-others-did-to-prepare-for-President-Romney.html?pg=all|accessdate=January 22, 2016|work=[[Deseret News]]|date=May 29, 2013}}</ref> In the foreword, Romney wrote, "My campaign was not successful but our Readiness Project team was."<ref name="ClarkReadiness">{{cite news|last1=Clark|first1=Charles|title=Romney Readiness Team Reunites to Review Lessons Learned|url=http://www.govexec.com/management/2013/05/romney-readiness-team-reunites-review-lessons-learned/63917/|accessdate=May 13, 2016|work=[[Government Executive]]|date=May 29, 2013}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|2010s|Conservatism}} * [[Mitt Romney presidential campaign, 2012]] * [[Presidential transition of Barack Obama]] * [[Presidential transition of Donald Trump]]

{{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Rakhrhya {{lang-pa|ਰੱਖੜੀਆ}} |native_name = |type = Secular |longtype = |image = Threads of love rakhi, Raksha Bandhan Hindus Sikhs Jains India.jpg |caption = Examples of Rakihrhya |official_name = Rakhrhya |nickname = Rakhar punya |observedby = [[Hindus]] [[Sikhs]] [[Christians]] |begins = |ends = |date = [[Purnima (day)|Puniya]] (full moon) of [[Sawan]] ਸਾਵਨ ਪੁੰਨਿਆ | date2015 = '''Saturday, August 29''' | date2016 = Thursday, August 18 | date2017 = Monday, August 7 | date2018 = Sunday, August 26 | date2019 = Thursday, August 15 | date2020 = Monday, August 3 |week_ordinal = |weekday = |month = |celebrations = |relatedto = }} '''Rakhri''' or Rakhrhee ({{lang-pa|ਰੱਖੜੀ}}) is the Punjabi word for [[Raksha Bandhan|Rakhi]] and a festival observed by [[Hindus]] and [[Sikhs]].Eleanor Nesbitt (2016) Sikhism: A Very Short Introduction. Oxford University Press[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=XebnCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA6&dq=sikhs+raksha+bandhan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwil9ZXF0KjdAhXKC8AKHT35DHEQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=sikhs%20raksha%20bandhan&f=false]Marian de Souza, Gloria Durka, Kathleen Engebretson, Robert Jackson, Andrew McGrad (2007) International Handbook of the Religious, Moral and Spiritual Dimensions in Education. Springer [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=KbdDAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA392&dq=punjab+christians+raksha+bandhan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjV3_yf0qjdAhWHLsAKHS6VBygQ6AEIPTAE#v=onepage&q=punjab%20christians%20raksha%20bandhan&f=false]People of India: A - G., Volume 4 (1998) Oxford Univ. Press[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=jHQMAQAAMAAJ&dq=punjabi++raksha+bandhan&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=+raksha+bandhan] In the [[Punjab region]], the festival of [[Raksha Bandhan]] is celebrated as '''Rakhrhya''' ({{lang-pa|ਰੱਖੜੀਆ}}).{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/society/raksha-bandhan-is-here/article6295502.ece|title=Raksha bandhan is here!|date=2014-08-08|newspaper=The Hindu|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X|access-date=2016-08-17}} Rakhrhya is observed on the same day of the lunar month of Sawan. It, like Raksha Bandhan, celebrates the relationship between brothers and sisters. Rakhri means “to protect” whereby a brother promises to look out for his sister and in return, a sister prays for the well being of her brother. A Rakhri can also be tied on a cousin or an unrelated man. If a woman ties a Rakhri on an unrelated man, their relationship is treated as any other brother and sister relationship would be. The festival is a siblings-day comparable to Mother's day/Father's day/Grandparents day etc.{{Cite web|url=http://www.siblingsdayfoundation.org/articles|title=Articles - Siblings Day Foundation|access-date=2016-08-17}} ==Celebration== A sister will tie the Rakhri on her brother and her brother will give a gift. Another feature of the celebration is the consumption of sweets.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YOI1nB_zTyAC&pg=PA101&dq=raksha+bandhan+sikh+women&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CE8Q6AEwCWoVChMIwba-7YnexwIVFEfbCh3lawop#v=onepage&q=raksha%20bandhan%20sikh%20women&f=false Kristen Haar, Sewa Singh Kalsi (2009) Sikhism] There is no special ceremony but a sister will sing folk songsPande, Alka (1999) Folk Music & Musical Instruments of Punjab: From Mustard Fields to Disco Lights, Volume 1 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=CgraAAAAMAAJ&dq=rakhri++punjab+soldiers&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=rakhri++] and say something along the lines of: [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]]:
''ਸੂਰਜ ਛੱਡੀਆਂ ਰਿਸ਼ਮਾਂ
''ਮੂਲੀ ਛੱਡਿਆਂ ਬੀਅ
''ਭੈਣ ਨੇ ਬੰਨੀ ਰੱਖੜੀ
'' ਜੁਗ ਜੁਗ ਵੀਰਾ ਜੀਅ
Alop ho riha Punjabi virsa - bhag dooja by Harkesh Singh Kehal Unistar Book PVT Ltd {{ISBN|978-93-5017-532-3}}
Transliteration:
''Suraj chhadya rishma''
''mooli chhadya bi''
''bhain ne banni rahkhree''
''jug jug veera ji

'''Social Innovation Camp''' (SICamp) is a competition and event for software developers, designers and social innovators to create new businesses and projects that use the web to achieve a social goal. It is a method for [[social innovation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nesta.org.uk/publications/reports/assets/features/the_open_book_of_social_innovation |title=Publications |website=Nesta.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-07-18}}</ref>
==History== Social Innovation Camp was set up in [[London]], in early 2008, with support from the [[Young Foundation]] and NESTA.
Social Innovation Camps have taken place:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://2.syd-az.net/xarici-tecrube |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-06-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110810161445/http://2.syd-az.net/xarici-tecrube |archivedate=2011-08-10 |df= }} </ref>
* April 2008 at the [[Young Foundation]] in [[Bethnal Green]], [[London]].<ref>[http://www.sicamp.org/?page_id=159] {{dead link|date=July 2016}}</ref> * December 2008 at the [[Young Foundation]] in [[Bethnal Green]], [[London]].<ref>[https://archive.is/20130415204500/http://www.sicamp.org/?page_id=319] </ref> * June 2009 at The Saltire Centre in [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]].<ref>[http://www.sicamp.org/?page_id=357] {{dead link|date=July 2016}}</ref> * 8–10 August 2009 in [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].<ref name="sicamp.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.sicamp.org/global |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111206062010/http://www.sicamp.org/global/ |archivedate=2011-12-06 |df= }} </ref> * September 2009 in [[Bratislava]], [[Slovakia]].<ref name="sicamp.org"/> * 5–7 March 2010 in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]].<ref name="http://www.sicamp.org/global">{{cite web |url=http://www.sicamp.org/global/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727162553/http://www.sicamp.org/global/ |archivedate=2011-07-27 |df= }} </ref> * 26–28 March 2010 at the [[Young Foundation]] in [[Bethnal Green]], [[London]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sicamp.org/si-camp-uk/previous-camps/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111027024712/http://www.sicamp.org/si-camp-uk/previous-camps/ |archivedate=2011-10-27 |df= }} </ref> * 18–19 September 2010, [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://1.syd-az.net/haqqinda/english |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-08 |deadurl=yes 2010, [[Lagos]], [[Nigeria]].<ref name="http://www.sicamp.org/global"/> * 27–29 May 2011, in [[Kyrgyzstan]].<ref name="http://www.sicamp.org/global"/> * 18–20 June 2011 at The Informatics Forum in [[Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sicamp.org/si-camp-uk/scotland-2011/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111027024717/http://www.sicamp.org/si-camp-uk/scotland-2011/ |archivedate=2011-10-27 |df= }} </ref> * 18–20 June 2011 in [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://2011.sicamp36.org/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111119012223/http://2011.sicamp36.org/ |accessdate=2011-05-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110502053559/http://2.syd-az.net/SYD-nedir/english |archivedate=2011-05-02 |df= }} </ref> * November 18–20, 2011, [[Yerevan]], [[Armenia]].<ref>[http://mardamej.wordpress.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111124023241/http://mardamej.wordpress.com/ |date=2011-11-24 }}</ref> * May 10–12, 2013, [[Oslo]], [[Norway]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sicamp.no/ideer-2013/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511054740/http://sicamp.no/ideer-2013/ |archivedate=2013-05-11 |df= }}</ref>
==Winners== *The winning project from the first event was Enabled By Design. *The winning project from the second camp was The Good Gym. *The winning project from the third camp was MyPolice. *The winning projects from the 8th camp were Yollar.info (project about transports in [[Baku]]) and Temizsaxlayaq.com (project about [[environment protection]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://1.syd-az.net/elanlar/syd_bash_tutdu |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728160849/http://1.syd-az.net/elanlar/syd_bash_tutdu |archivedate=2011-07-28 |df= }} </ref>
==International Camps== The Social Innovation Camp model has been replicated in [[Australia]], [[Slovakia]], [[South Korea]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Armenia]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Nigeria]], [[Kyrgyzstan]] and [[Azerbaijan]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://globalvoices.org/2010/04/19/caucasus-social-innovation-camp/ |title=Caucasus: Social Innovation Camp · Global Voices |website=Globalvoices.org |date=2010-04-19 |accessdate=2016-07-18}}</ref>
"[[Transitions Online]]" organized the Social Innovation Camp in [[Azerbaijan]] (July 23–24, 2011).<ref name="bare_url" /> Organisers for International Social Innovation Camps include [[Soros Foundation]], [[The Hope Institute]], [[International Research & Exchanges Board|IREX]], [[UNDP]], [[Internews]], [[The Eurasia Partnership Foundation]], [[World Wide Narrative]] and others.
==Media interest== Social Innovation Camps have been featured by a number of media outlets including [[The Guardian]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/socialinnovationcamp |title=Social innovation camp | Technology |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date= |accessdate=2016-07-18}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Social Innovation]] *[[Young Foundation]] *[[Transitions Online]]

'''Solar wind Magnetosphere Ionosphere Link Explorer''' ('''SMILE''') is a planned joint venture mission between the [[European Space Agency]] and the [[Chinese Academy of Sciences]] to study the interaction between [[Earth's magnetic field|Earth's magnetosphere]] and the [[solar wind]], while simultaneously monitoring the magnetosphere's [[Plasma (physics)|plasma environment]].<ref name="ESAstudySMILE">{{cite web |url=http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Space_Science/ESA_and_Chinese_Academy_of_Sciences_to_study_Smile_as_joint_mission|title=ESA and Chinese Academy of Sciences to study Smile as joint mission |publisher=ESA |date=22 June 2015 |accessdate=October 2015}}</ref><ref name="SMILE-RFI" /> Launch is expected at the end of 2021.<ref name="ICLFirstHurdle">{{cite news |url=http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/newsandeventspggrp/imperialcollege/newssummary/news_4-6-2015-12-39-12 |title=Solar wind monitoring mission passes the first hurdle |publisher=[[Imperial College London]] |first1=Hayley |last1=Dunning |date=4 June 2015 |accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref>
== Overview ==
SMILE will be equipped to simultaneously capture images and movies of the [[magnetopause]], [[polar cusp]]s, and [[aurora]].<ref name="ESAstudySMILE" /> Traditionally, satellites have taken local measurements of different regions to build up a global picture of the [[magnetosphere]]. However, a recent discovery that the magnetosphere emits X-rays will allow SMILE to capture more comprehensive data than previous missions did through the analysis of these X-rays.<ref name="ICLFirstHurdle" />
Key instruments on board the spacecraft will include:<ref name="ICLFirstHurdle" /><ref name="proposal">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mssl.ucl.ac.uk/~gbr/SMILE/images/SMILE_Executive_Summary.pdf| title = Joint Scientific Space Mission Chinese Academy of Science (CAS) - European Space Agency (ESA) PROPOSAL SMILE: Solar wind Magnetosphere Ionosphere Link Explorer | first1=Graziella | last1=Branduardi-Raymon | first2=Chi | last2=Wang |format=PDF |accessdate=4 June 2015 }}</ref> * '''Soft [[X-ray]] Imager''' (SXI) – used to study the interaction of the solar wind with Earth's magnetosphere. Telescope will be developed by scientists from the [[University of Leicester]].<ref name="LeicesterM">{{cite web|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-space-scientists-develop-space/story-26636671-detail/story.html|title=Leicester space scientists develop space satellite which predicts solar storms|publisher=[[Leicester Mercury]]|date=4 June 2015|accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref> * '''[[Ultraviolet|UV]] Imager''' (UVI) – used to observe and measure the [[aurora borealis]] along with identifying polar cap boundaries. Telescope will use a four-mirror design along with new filters. * '''Light Ion Analyser''' (LIA) – on site measurement of ions in the solar wind. * '''Magnetometer''' (MAG) – on site measurement of magnetic fields.
The mission consists of a propulsion module and service module provided by the CAS, and a payload module containing all of the scientific instruments and an X-band communications system by the ESA. The launch will be conducted by ESA, while the Mission Operations Centre will be run by CAS; both organizations will jointly operate the Science Operations Centre.<ref name="SMILE-RFI">{{cite web|url=http://sci.esa.int/cosmic-vision/57064-request-for-information-rfi-for-the-provision-of-the-payload-module-for-the-joint-esa-china-smile-mission/ |title=Request for Information (RFI) for the provision of the payload module for the joint ESA-China SMILE mission |publisher=[[ESA]] |date=18 December 2015 |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref>
The spacecraft is currently planned for launch in 2021 to a [[Molniya orbit]] with an [[apogee]] of 20 {{Earth radius}} ([[Earth radii]], where 1 {{Earth radius}} = 6,371 km) using a European Launch Vehicle. Mission cost is estimated to be {{Euro|92 million}}.<ref name="proposal" />
==History== Following the success of the [[Double Star (satellite)|Double Star]] mission, the ESA and [[Chinese Academy of Sciences|CAS]] decided to jointly select, design, implement, and launch a space mission together for the first time. After initial workshops, a call for proposals was announced in January 2015. After a joint [[peer review]] of mission proposals, SMILE was selected as the top candidate out of 16 proposed.<ref name="ESAstudySMILE" /> The SMILE mission proposal was jointly led by the [[University College London]] and the Chinese National Space Science Center. From June to November 2015, the mission entered initial studies for concept readiness, and final approval was given for the mission by the ESA Science Programme Committee in November 2015.<ref name="ICLFirstHurdle" /><ref name="SMILE-RFI" />
A Request For Information (RFI) on provisions for the payload module was announced on 18 December 2015. The objective was to collect information from potential providers to assess low risk payload module requirements given stated interest in the mission, in preparation for the Invitation to Tender in 2016.<ref name="SMILE-RFI" />

[[Image:Andrea Maria Schenkel1.jpg|thumb|[[Andrea Maria Schenkel]]]]
'''''Tannöd''''' is a novel by German author [[Andrea Maria Schenkel]]. It was first published in Germany in January 2006 and was adapted for film in 2009.
== Contents == The novel narrates the story of a multiple murder at an isolated Bavarian farm called Tannöd in the 1950s. The points-of-view of the victims, the witnesses and the perpetrator are intertwined in 39 short passages. Through these largely separate testimonies, the reader gradually builds a complete picture of the events that lead a rural family, headed by a tyrannical, abusive father to all be brutally murdered.
== Background == The novel is based on the unsolved murder of an entire family in 1922 on the farmstead [[Hinterkaifeck]], Bavaria.
== Adaptations ==
A film adaptation of the novel with the same title ''Tannöd'' was released in cinemas in Germany on 19 November 2009, directed by [[Bettina Oberli]], (Wüste-Film West) and starring [[Julia Jentsch]], [[Monica Bleibtreu]] and [[Volker Bruch]].
== Awards ==
* ''2007'': [[Deutscher Krimi Preis]], Friedrich Glauser Prize * ''2008'': Swedish Crime Fiction Prize. * ''Audiobook'': [[Corine Literature Prize|CORINE-Weltbild-Leserpreis]].
== Publication history == By May 2009 one million copies had been sold of the novel ''Tannöd''.<ref>[http://www.andreaschenkel.de/1_buecher_1tannoed.html Information on ''Tannöd''] on Andrea Maria Schenkel's Homepage.</ref> The English translation of the novel was released by Quercus Publishing on 5 June 2008. The title is ''The Murder Farm''. Quercus released a paperback edition of ''The Murder Farm'' on 26 December 2008.
== Bibliography ==
* Andrea Maria Schenkel: ''Tannöd'', Edition Nautilus, Hamburg 2006, {{ISBN|978-3-89401-479-7}} * Andrea Maria Schenkel: ''Tannöd'', btb, Munich 2008, {{ISBN|978-3-442-73673-7}}

[[2016 Mazda Road to Indy Shootout]] ([[Oliver Askew|Askew]]) |team titles = |folded = }} The '''Team USA Scholarship''' is a scholarship program to allow [[American people|American]] racing drivers to compete overseas. The competition selects young talents to compete in select auto events. ==History== ===Formula Ford Festival (part 1)=== [[File:Bryan Herta 2004 Indianapolis 500 Third Qual Day.JPG|left|thumb|150px|Winner of the 1991 scholarship, [[Bryan Herta]]. ]] The event was launched late in the 1990 racing season. The Scholarship was set up with initial support from [[IndyCar Series]] team owner [[Rick Galles]], gentleman racer and business owner [[Jonathan Holtzman]] and [[Ford]] [[Special Vehicle Operations]].{{cite web|title=Vasser For FF Festival|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1733|website=Team USA Scholarship|accessdate=6 November 2017}} [[Canadian Formula Ford 2000]] graduate [[Jimmy Vasser]] and [[United States Auto Club|USAC]] Sprint Car champion [[Jeff Gordon]] were selected to compete at the [[Formula Ford Festival]]. As Gordon had prior commitments in midget racing, so only Vasser made the trip to [[Brands Hatch]]. Vasser raced a [[Lanan Racing|Lanan]] 1604 chassis. The young American was involved in a crash with [[Steffan Nielsen]] in the heat race which ended is Festival.{{cite web|title=History|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?page_id=110|website=Team USA Scholarship|accessdate=6 November 2017}} The following year the Scholarship again partnered with Lanan Racing, now racing a [[Reynard Motorsports|Reynard]] chassis.{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1724|title=Herta to Represent U.S. in World Cup|last=|first=|date=1991-10-19|website=Team USA Scholarship|accessdate=7 November 2017}} Herta qualified for the final race in 15th place and worked his way up to eleventh place.{{Cite web|url=http://www.motorsportmagazine.com/archive/article/december-1991/48/interview-bryan-herta|title=Interview -- Bryan Herta|last=|first=|date=01-12-1991|website=Motorsport Magazine|accessdate=7 November 2017}} For 1992 two drivers were chosen to compete, [[Tony Ave]] and [[Ashton Lewis]]. The racers were selected after a test session at [[Snetterton Circuit|Snetterton]].{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1712|title=Ave and Lewis to Represent U.S. in Formula Ford Festival|last=|first=|date=11-09-1992|website=Team USA Scholarship|accessdate=7 November 2017}} [[Primus Racing]]/[[John Village Automotive]] entered three [[Van Diemen]] RF92 chassis. Two were driven by Ave and Lewis, a third was driven by [[Geoff Boss]] as a guest driver.{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1709|title=Team USA Impresses in Shakedown Test|last=|first=|date=|website=Team USA Scholarship|accessdate=7 November 2017}} Boss was the fastest American driver qualifying fourth, but as his car did not pass technical inspection he had to start from the back of the grid.{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1706|title=Team USA Out of Luck in Qualifying|last=|first=|date=|website=Team USA Scholarship|accessdate=7 November 2017}} Lewis was the best Team USA Scholarship driver in the 1992 Formula Ford Festival finishing fifteenth. Boss was unable to advance after starting last in his heat race. Ave collided with [[John Oxborrow]] in his heat race and failed to finish.{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1703|title=Lewis Finishes Fifth at Brands Hatch|last=|first=|date=|website=Team USA Scholarship|accessdate=7 November 2017}} [[Jerry Nadeau]] was the sole driver selected for the Team USA Scholarship for 1993. The [[North Carolina]] native qualified on pole position for his heat race, winning the race in his year old Van Diemen RF92. He won the race with an advantage of over 26 seconds over [[Jan Neumann]].{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1683|title=Nadeau Scores Stunning Victory in Fastest Heat Race|last=|first=|date=|website=Team USA Scholarship|access-date=}} AFter a second place in the semi-final race, Nadeau started the final in third. Racing with other young talents such as [[Craig Lowndes]] and [[Jan Erik Löfgren]] Nadeau had to settle for fourth place.{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1680|title=Nadeau Claims Fighting Fourth in Thrilling Festival Finale|last=|first=|date=|website=Team USA Scholarship|access-date=}} [[Mike Borkwoski]] and [[Clay Collier]] were selected to race in the Formula Ford Festival [[Ford Zetec|Zetec]] class. The Festival was unsuccessful for both drivers with neither progressing into the final race.{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1672|title=Team USA Shut out in Formula Ford Festival|last=|first=|date=|website=Team USA Scholarship|access-date=}} ===International F3 Trophy=== For 1995 Team USA Scholarship had an agreement with [[Dick Bennetts]], team owner of [[West Surrey Racing]] to field a [[Mugen Motorsports|Mugen]]-[[Honda]] powered [[Dallara]] F395 for a selected driver in the International Formula 3 Trophy. The race was run at [[Donington Park]] on 22 October 1995.{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1669|title=Vasser, Herta Confirm Worth of Team USA Scholarship|last=|first=|date=2017-11-15|website=Team USA Scholarship|access-date=}} [[Memo Gidley]] was selected and qualified the car in 16th position. Gidley finished the race in eleventh place after lengthy battles with [[Marc Cramer]] and [[Thomas Schwister]].{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1654|title=Gidley Displays His Racecraft on F3 Debut|last=|first=|date=2017-11-15|website=Team USA Scholarship|access-date=}} [[Owen McAuley]] won the race with [[Jason Elliott (racing driver)|Jason Elliott]] and [[Scott Lakin]] completing the podium.{{Cite web|url=http://www.motorsportmagazine.com/archive/article/december-1995/4/month-motor-sport|title=The month in Motor Sport|last=|first=|date=2007-11-15|website=Motorsport Magazine|access-date=}} ===EFDA Nations Cup=== With Formula 3 deemed to expensive, the Team USA Scholarship returned to more affordable racing. The [[EFDA Nations Cup]] was selected, being a one-make series all drivers raced equal material. The cars were [[Reynard Motorsports|Reynard]] [[Formula Opel Lotus]] single seaters. [[Tony Renna]] was selected out of six finalists.{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1647|title=Tony Renna Wins 1996 Team USA Scholarship|last=|first=|date=2017-11-15|website=Team USA Scholarship|access-date=}} [[Jerry Nadeau]] racing in the 1996 Eruopean Formula Opel Lotus championship, joined Renna in the Nations Cup event.{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1642|title=Nadeau to Represent America in Nations Cup VII|last=|first=|date=2017-11-15|website=Team USA Scholarship|access-date=}} After two races the team placed second in the overall standings of the [[1996 EFDA Nations Cup]], scoring the silver medal. The team returned to the Nations Cup in 1997 with [[Buddy Rice]] and [[Matt Sielsky]].{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1628|title=Rice, Sielsky Win 1997 Team USA Scholarships|last=|first=|date=2017-11-15|website=Team USA Scholarship|access-date=}} [[Paul Edwards (racing driver)|Paul Edwards]] was selected as a third driver, racing in the [[Formula Ford Festival]]. Edwards started fifth in the Festival race and worked his way up to third. Unfortunately, a run in with [[Robert Lechner (racing driver)|Robert Lechner]] caused Edwards to retire. In the Nations Cup Rice and Sielsky struggled in qualifying with the setup and the team had to settle for fifth.{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1608|title=Team USA Places Fifth; Edwards Stars in World Cup|last=|first=|date=2017-11-15|website=Team USA Scholarship|access-date=}} In 1998 Team USA Scholarship supported Paul Edwards in the final three rounds of the [[Formula Opel Euroseries]] and the EFDA Formula Opel Lotus Winter Series. His best finish was a fifth place at the Nürburgring with a Team USA Scholarship supported [[Motaworld Racing]] entry.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dlg.speedfreaks.org/archive/1998/fopel.html|title=Formula Opel Euroseries|last=|first=|date=|website=The GEL Motorsport Information Page|access-date=}} In the Winter Series Edwards raced with [[Team Meritus]]. Edwards won at [[Donington Park]] and placed second at the [[Hockenheimring]]. Leading the championship into the final round, again at the Hockenheimring, Edwards won the championship by default as the final was canceled. Freezing winter conditions caused the organisation to abandon the final event. Edwards won the championship over other contenders such as [[Richard Lyons (racing driver)|Richard Lyons]] and [[Takuma Sato]].{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1586|title=Cancellation Ensures Edwards’ Championship|last=|first=|date=2017-11-15|website=Team USA Scholarship|access-date=}} ===Formula Palmer Audi (part 1)=== For 1999 Team USA Scholarship shifted focus to the [[Formula Palmer Audi]] Winter Series. A series set up by former Formula 1 driver [[Jonathan Palmer]] featuring one-make [[Van Diemen]] chassis powered by 1.8L [[Audi]] engines. Three drivers were selected to compete, [[Paul Edwards (racing driver)|Paul Edwards]], [[Andy Lally]] and [[Jeff Simmons (racing driver)|Jeff Simmons]] were selected to compete.{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1584|title=Team USA Scholarship Expands to Three-Car Effort|last=|first=|date=2017-11-15|website=Team USA Scholarship|access-date=}} Edwards won three out of four races (at [[Snetterton Circuit|Snetterton]] and [[Brands Hatch]]), with [[Paul Munn]] winning the fourth race. Edwards won the championship with an 8-point advantage.{{Cite web|url=http://motorsportwinners.com/defunct/formula-palmer-audi-winter-series/|title=Formula Palmer Audi Winter Series (1998-2008)|last=|first=|date=2017-11-15|website=Motorsport Winners|access-date=}} Lally finished fifth, Simmons eighth.{{Cite web|url=https://www.driverdb.com/championships/standings/formula-palmer-audi-winter-series/1999/|title=Formula Palmer Audi Winter Series 1999 standings|last=|first=|date=2017-11-15|website=DriverDB.com|access-date=}} [[Phil Giebler]] and [[Joey Hand]] were selected for Team USA Scholarship for the 2000 Formula Palmer Audi Winter Series.{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1567|title=Six Young Americans Selected for Scholarship Shootout|last=|first=|date=2017-11-15|website=Team USA Scholarship|access-date=}} Giebler scored three podiums and a win at Brands Hatch to claim the title. Hand scored a single podium finish, a second place at Snetterton, to settle for sixth in the championship.{{Cite web|url=https://www.driverdb.com/championships/standings/formula-palmer-audi-winter-series/2000/|title=Formula Palmer Audi Winter Series 2000 standings|last=|first=|date=2017-11-15|website=DriverDB.com|access-date=}} ===New Zealand Formula Ford=== In November 2001 twelve drivers were selected for a shootout style event at the [[Jim Russell Racing Driver School]]. [[A.J. Allmendinger]] and [[Bryan Sellers]] were selected for the 2001 Team USA Scholarship.{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1556|title=Allmendinger, Sellers Earn 2001 Team USA Scholarships|last=|first=|date=2017-11-15|website=Team USA Scholarship|access-date=}} Due to the relative inexperience with single seaters, Team USA Scholarship returned to [[Formula Ford]], in [[New Zealand Formula Ford Championship|New Zealand]]. The duo raced a partial season, with successes. Sellers won two races, both at [[Timaru International Motor Raceway|Timaru]], and placed ninth in the series championship.{{Cite web|url=https://www.driverdb.com/championships/standings/formula-ford-new-zealand/2002/|title=2001-02 Talley's Formula Ford Championship|last=|first=|date=2017-11-15|website=DriverDB.com|access-date=}} Sellers and Allmendinger placed second and third at the [[New Zealand Grand Prix]], behind [[Fabian Coulthard]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.motorsport.org.nz/Results/060102FFr2.htm|title=P&O Nedlloyd New Zealand Grand Prix|last=|first=|date=2017-11-15|website=Motorsport New Zealand|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020225114802/http://www.motorsport.org.nz/Results/060102FFr2.htm|archive-date=2002-02-25|dead-url=yes|access-date=|df=}} For 2003, three drivers were selected for the six race New Zealand International Formula Ford Series. [[Joe D'Agostino (racing driver)|Joe D'Agostino]], [[Charlie Kimball]] and [[Ryan Millen]]. Millen, who is of New Zealand ancestry, is the nephew of [[1980 New Zealand Grand Prix]] winner [[Steve Millen]].{{Cite web|url=http://teamusascholarship.org/?p=1524|title=Three American Youngsters Set To Contest New Zealand Formula Ford Series|last=|first=|date=03-12-2017|website=Team USA Scholarship|access-date=}} ==Representatives== {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{Infobox television episode | title = Tikka to Ride | series = [[Red Dwarf]] | image = Tikka to Ride (Red Dwarf).jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Rimmer, Cat, Lister, and Kryten are held an gunpoint by authorities at the [[Texas School Book Depository]] | series_no = 7 | episode = 1 | director = [[Ed Bye]] | writer = [[Doug Naylor]] | airdate = 17 January 1997 | guests = * [[Michael J. Shannon]] as [[John F. Kennedy]] * Toby Aspin as [[Lee Harvey Oswald]] * Peter Gaitens as FBI Agent * Robert Ashe as Cop | prev = [[Out of Time (Red Dwarf)|Out of Time]] | next = [[Stoke Me a Clipper]] | episode_list = List of Red Dwarf episodes }} "'''Tikka To Ride'''" is the first episode of [[science fiction]] [[sitcom]] ''[[Red Dwarf]]'' Series VII and the 37th in the series run. It was first broadcast on the British television channel [[BBC Two|BBC2]] on 17 January 1997.<ref name="BBC - Programme Catalogue - RED DWARF VI - TIKKA TO RIDE">{{cite web | url =http://catalogue.bbc.co.uk/catalogue/infax/programme/NMYJ411X | title =BBC - Programme Catalogue - RED DWARF VI - TIKKA TO RIDE | publisher =BBC |accessdate =12 December 2007}}</ref> Written by [[Doug Naylor]] and directed by [[Ed Bye]], it was the first episode not to involve co-creator and writer [[Rob Grant]].
Series VII was the first series to have extended episodes.
==Plot== [[Dave Lister|Lister]] makes a video explaining how the crew survived [[Out of Time (Red Dwarf)|their battle]] with their future selves. If the future crew had killed their former selves, they would have eliminated their own existence, and therefore not have been able to destroy themselves. (See [[temporal paradox]].) Therefore, time has reset to a point before the crew picked up time drive. Lister's explanation is too convoluted for the video camera to handle and it explodes. [[Kryten]] dismisses the whole incident as "garbled" and more "boring than an in-flight magazine produced by [[Air Belgium (1979–2000)|Air Belgium]]."
Unfortunately disaster has struck - ''[[Red Dwarf ships#Starbug|Starbug]]'' is still damaged from the battle and as a consequence all the [[Indian food]] supplies have been destroyed; not even a single [[papadum]] survived. Lister proposes that the crew obtain the time drive again and go back in time to an Indian take-away and order 500 curries (even though [[Out of Time (Red Dwarf)|Out of Time]] established that travel to other places (such as Earth) would also require a star drive). [[Arnold Rimmer|Rimmer]], [[Cat (Red Dwarf)|Cat]] and Kryten are against the idea and oppose going back in time, having seen the kind of people they could possibly become. Lister argues that they can use a time drive and avoid that consequence if they don't abuse it like their future selves did; however he finds himself outnumbered and seemingly concedes defeat. However, Lister swaps Kryten's head for one of his spare heads and removes the guilt chip from it, having the now guiltless Kryten reassure the crew that it will be okay. The next morning, Rimmer and Cat are confused when Kryten serves them high-calorie breakfasts, starts smoking and using phrases like ''"you bet your ass"''. However, when Kryten assures them it'll be ok to pick up the time drive the two assent and board the ship containing it, intending to go back to the 21st Century to one of Lister's favourite curry houses to pick up a large order.
Their [[time travel]] calculations are a little off and they find themselves in [[Dallas, Texas]] on 22 November 1963. They appear at the [[Texas School Book Depository]] just as [[Lee Harvey Oswald]] is [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|firing]] at U.S. President [[John F. Kennedy]]. They inadvertently knock him out the window to his death below, thereby preventing Kennedy's assassination. The crew use the time travel device, to go three years forward to 1966.
The crew find Dallas deserted. Wandering the streets, they find a man who has been trampled to death, indicating people left in a hurry. Reading a nearby newspaper, Kryten finds out what has happened:
{{quote|President Kennedy was impeached in 1964 for sharing a mistress with Mafia boss, Sam Giancana. It was the biggest scandal in American history. Kennedy was sentenced to three years in an open prison in July, '65. J. Edgar Hoover became president; he was forced to run by the mob, who had pictures of him at a transvestite orgy...Soon after his election, the USSR were allowed to install a nuclear base in Cuba in return for Mafia cocaine trafficking between Cuba and the States. With a Soviet nuclear base 30 miles from the US mainland, people fled from all the major cities.}}
The crew attempt to correct the situation by returning to the day of the shooting and driving Oswald to a higher floor in the building, but this plan still fails to lead to Kennedy's death; by sending Oswald up another floor, they made the shot's trajectory so steep that Kennedy was merely wounded. Lister suggests getting a second gunman to shoot from behind a nearby grassy knoll. With none of the crew willing to shoot the President themselves, Lister travels to [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|Idlewild Airport]] in 1965 and persuades a post-impeachment Kennedy to travel back to 1963, become a "second gunman" on the [[grassy knoll]], and shoot himself to restore his place in history. The plan works: Kennedy shoots his past self and the timeline is restored. Kennedy grimly thanks the gang for the chance to restore himself to his proper place in history, and fades away as a result of the resetting timeline. Lister, too late, realises he forgot to ask Kennedy for the name of a good Indian take-away. Having seen that Lister has learned absolutely nothing from the experience, the other members of the crew give him a well-deserved beating in return for all he's put them through.
===Extended Edition/Alternate Ending===
Shown as an option on the Series 7 DVD, the Extended Edition of ''Tikka To Ride'' continues after Cat, Rimmer and Kryten take out their frustrations on Lister. After managing to correctly use the time drive and steal the Indian food supplies from Starbug before the events of the episode began (thus showing an example of a predestination paradox and allowing Lister to re-stock on curry, papadums and lager), the crew end up storing the food in one of Starbug's cargo holds (ostensibly the same cargo hold it was stolen from in the first place - B-deck). Rimmer leaves with Kryten in tow but remarks as he does ''"I must've passed this thing a million times. What the hell's it for?"'' in regards to a lever by the door. It doesn't take long for Lister to give into the curiosity planted by Rimmer and pull the lever. The lever, in fact, activates the separation sequence for Starbug, jettisoning the rear section of the ship into space while allowing the front half to fly away; an ace Rimmer had ''"had up his sleeve for months"''. Lister notes that he's stranded alone in deep space with nothing but three-and-a-half tons of curry, and couldn't be happier before eagerly digging into the crates.
==Production== Even though the previous series had ended on a cliffhanger, fans had been forced to wait three years for the resolution. This was due to a number of factors, which included [[Craig Charles]] being imprisoned before being cleared of a charge of [[rape]],<ref>{{cite news |date=31 July 2003 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/3055859.stm |title= The trauma of being falsely accused |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=27 December 2006}}</ref> [[Chris Barrie]] making no secret of his desire to leave the show,<ref name="Red Dwarf Series VII Writing">{{cite web | url =http://www.reddwarf.co.uk/deck05/series_7/writing.html | title =Red Dwarf Series VII Writing | publisher =Red Dwarf.co.uk |accessdate =17 December 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071022124350/http://reddwarf.co.uk/deck05/series_7/writing.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 22 October 2007}}</ref> and most notably Rob Grant deciding to leave the series, ending his and Doug Naylor's long-standing writing partnership.<ref name="Red Dwarf Series VII Writing"/> Naylor was left with the choice of either ending or continuing the series. Although tempted to end it, he later agreed to write two more eight-episode series of the show, as this would allow the episode count to reach 52 and therefore be eligible for [[Television syndication|syndication]].<ref name="Red Dwarf Series VII Writing"/>
"Tikka To Ride" ushered in new production values. The cinematic quality and filming of the new episodes meant that the studio audience was no longer viable (however the show was shown to an audience at a later date and their laughter was added). Also the special effects were increasing every series and the majority of the episodes were pre-recorded.<ref name="Red Dwarf Series VII Production">{{cite web | url =http://www.reddwarf.co.uk/deck05/series_7/production.html | title =Red Dwarf Series VII Production | publisher =Red Dwarf.co.uk |accessdate =17 December 2007|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071022124317/http://reddwarf.co.uk/deck05/series_7/production.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 22 October 2007}}</ref> One of Naylor's desires for a seventh series was the prospect of international syndication and a movie.<ref name="Red Dwarf Series VII Production"/> This vision was helped with the return of [[Ed Bye]] to the director's chair, having previously left due to a scheduling clash with directing his wife [[Ruby Wax]]'s new TV show at the time.<ref name="Interview: Ed Bye">Interview: Ed Bye, Red Dwarf smegazine, issue 12, January 1993, Fleetway Editions Ltd, {{ISSN|0965-5603}}</ref> He agreed to return to helm the seventh series, his first Red Dwarf episode since Series IV's "[[Meltdown (Red Dwarf)|Meltdown]]".
The arrival of the seventh series was also promoted by the show making its first appearance of the front cover of the [[Radio Times]].
Guest stars included [[Michael J. Shannon]] who played John F. Kennedy, Toby Aspin as Lee Harvey Oswald, Peter Gaitens as FBI Agent and Robert Ashe as Cop.
The deserted Dallas scenes were filmed at [[Farnborough Airport]]. The expanded Starbug cargo deck scenes were filmed inside the former [[Royal Aircraft Establishment]] wind tunnels at Farnborough. The motorcade scenes were filmed at the [[Chobham]] test track, with additional crowd shots filmed around buildings at [[Shepperton Studios]].
==Cultural and historical references== The title of this episode is a piece of word-play based on the name of the song "[[Ticket to Ride]]" by [[the Beatles]], in accordance with the theme of curry on which the storyline focuses, tikka being an Indian spice marinade.
When on the [[Grassy Knoll]], Lister, Rimmer and Cat are dressed up as tramps, an outfit which the normally vain and shallow Cat would not be seen dead in: "Superficial is my middle name".<ref>''[[Back to Reality (Red Dwarf)|Back to Reality]]'', Red Dwarf Series V, episode 6, March 1992</ref> This was based on the [[Three tramps]], men that are reported to have been found in a [[boxcar]] behind the Grassy Knoll when the police searched it after the shooting, but were later released. Conspiracy theorists have assumed that they were part of the assassination plot.<ref name="Posner_Case_Closed">{{cite book|title=Case Closed|first=Gerald|last=Posner|authorlink=Gerald Posner|year=1993|publisher=Warner Books}}</ref>
The concept of the crew travelling backwards in time and accidentally saving someone's life, leading to a change for the worse in history, was also used in the ''[[Star Trek]]'' episode ''[[The City on the Edge of Forever]]''. In each case the person saved was actually an advocate of peace; however, there were few other similarities between the episodes.
In the commentary for the Series III episode "[[Timeslides]]" when talking about Kryten's shouting "Duck!" at the Grassy Knoll line, they note how their characters actually did something similar later on.
==Plot inconsistencies== At the start of the episode, Lister explains that the crew survived the [[Out of Time (Red Dwarf episode)|previous cliffhanger]] because of a [[temporal paradox]], which made it impossible for them to be killed by their future selves. However, later in the same episode, Kennedy is able to kill his younger self without creating the same paradox. There is no explanation of why there is one rule for the crew of Starbug and another for Kennedy. Similarly, it is explained that by preventing the initial assassination, Russia wins the space race (this is why Starbug disappears). This means the JMC never exists and the time drive would never have been found in the first place.
In the previous episode it was made clear that the time drive was only a ''time'' drive and not a space and time drive, so the crew could travel forward or backward in time but were still stuck in deep space. It was not explained in the episode how the time drive can suddenly transport them through space, or why, given that they could travel to 1963 Earth, they did not simply travel back to 22nd Century Earth as per their original plan.
On the Red Dwarf VII DVD documentary ''Back from the Dead'', director Ed Bye recalled explaining to a fan that the time drive was made up, and was just a lump of plastic.
==Reception== "Tikka to Ride" has generally been well received by critics. DVDActive called it "a promising start to the series" and noted that it was "beautifully shot, with a movie-style score".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dvdactive.com/reviews/dvd/red-dwarf-vii.html |title=Red Dwarf VII (UK - DVD R2) |publisher=www.dvdactive.com |accessdate=5 March 2014}}</ref> DVD Verdict stated "what other sitcom, sci-fi or otherwise, would take on the Kennedy Assassination and an alternative future for the United States had the beloved President not been felled by a rain of bullets?" and concluded that the episode "was majestic".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/reddwarfseries58.php |title=Red Dwarf: Series 5-8 |publisher=www.dvdverdict.com |accessdate=5 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080119032101/http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/reddwarfseries58.php |archivedate=19 January 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Sci-Fi Online noted that "''Tikka to Ride'' morphs into a surprisingly serious time paradox" but felt that the final plot twist was "a largely pointless contrivance."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sci-fi-online.com/reviews/dvd/05-11-07_RedDwarf7.htm |title=DVD Red Dwarf Series 7 |publisher=www.sci-fi-online.com |accessdate=5 March 2014}}</ref> BellaOnline called the episode "pure silliness, and I mean of the kind that makes ''Red Dwarf'' great."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bellaonline.com/articles/art40890.asp |title=DVD Review--"Red Dwarf Series VII" |publisher=www.bellaonline.com |accessdate=5 March 2014}}</ref>
